name: Inner-City Muslim Action Network
mission: IMAN provides transitional housing, life skills education, and sustainable construction training for returning citizens in Chicago and Atlanta.
theoryOfChange: The Inner-City Muslim Action Network (IMAN) outlines its strategic approach through sections like 'Principles of Change' and 'Strategic Initiatives' on its website. IMAN models an integrative approach that employs holistic interventions to address systemic injustices, fostering health, wellness, and healing in urban populations. Their Strategic Initiatives department is responsible for leading impact, innovation, and mission advancement opportunities, including incubating new programs and spearheading ideas from execution to institutionalization.
zakatClaimEvidence: Dedicated zakat page found at https://imancentral.org/donate (Source: https://imancentral.org/donate)

components.evidence: Explicit zakat program (+4); Muslim-focused organization (+2); Islamic identity (+1); Humanitarian service (+2)
components.name: Muslim Donor Fit

alignment.rationale: Alignment 34/50: MEDIUM Muslim donor fit, humanitarian cause area

components.evidence: No beneficiary data; moderate program ratio (≥65%)
components.improvement_suggestion: Track and report beneficiary counts to enable cost analysis
components.name: Cost Per Beneficiary

components.improvement_suggestion: Build working capital reserves to 1-3 months of operating expenses
components.name: Financial Health

components.improvement_suggestion: Seek external evaluation or track outcomes for 3+ years
components.name: Evidence & Outcomes

score_details.score_summary: INNER-CITY MUSLIM ACTION NETWORK earns 48/100 due to good alignment and limited impact, with zakat compliance (minor risk deductions applied).

all_citations.claim: IMAN holds 9.9 months of working capital and provides reentry and health services.
The organization is zakat-eligible and follows specific policies for asnaf categories.
IMAN provides multiple donation methods for supporters.
Volunteer opportunities are available for community engagement.
Total revenue was $15,923,414 with a program expense ratio of 65.9% and fundraising efficiency of $0.03 per $1 raised.

baseline_narrative.amal_score_rationale: IMAN demonstrates a moderate overall score of 48/100, reflecting a balance between strong financial stability and the need for more robust external impact verification.
areas_for_improvement: program expense ratio of 65.9% suggests room to increase the proportion of spending dedicated directly to program services [5].
Limited third-party impact data available to verify long-term cost-effectiveness per beneficiary [1].

dimension_explanations.alignment: With an alignment score of 34/50, IMAN shows strong resonance with Muslim donors through its zakat-eligible status and focus on urgent humanitarian causes like recidivism and urban poverty [2][3]. The organization offers diverse engagement opportunities, from financial donations to local volunteering, fostering a medium-to-high donor fit within the community [3][4].
dimension_explanations.impact: IMAN's impact score of 16/50 reflects its role as a direct service provider in health and reentry services, though data on specific cost-per-beneficiary outcomes remains limited [1][5]. While the organization reported a total revenue of $15,923,414, its program expense ratio is 65.9%, indicating a significant portion of funds is also directed toward administrative and operational infrastructure [5].

baseline_narrative.headline: The Inner-City Muslim Action Network (IMAN) drives social justice and community health through holistic services for marginalized populations in Chicago and Atlanta.
strengths: Strong financial liquidity with 9.9 months of working capital available to sustain operations [1].
High fundraising efficiency, spending only $0.03 to raise every $1 in contributions [5].
Direct community impact through integrated health, housing, and green reentry programs [1][4].
baseline_narrative.summary: IMAN provides essential services including transitional housing, sustainable construction training, and healthcare for returning citizens and local residents [1][5]. The organization is recognized as zakat-eligible, allowing donors to fulfill their religious obligations through programs that support specific asnaf categories [2].

areas_for_improvement.detail: With a <cite id="9">program expense ratio of 65.9%</cite>, the organization falls below the <cite id="14">peer median of 89.7%</cite>, indicating a higher relative spend on administration.
There is currently <cite id="15">no third-party impact evaluation</cite> or public beneficiary count data available to verify long-term cost-effectiveness.

bbb_assessment.summary: IMAN is currently unrated by the BBB Wise Giving Alliance.

case_against.mitigation_notes: The organization maintains high liquidity to buffer against revenue volatility.
risk_factors: <cite id="18">Significant revenue decline over the last three years</cite>
case_against.summary: The primary concerns involve <cite id="9">lower-than-average program spending</cite> and a <cite id="18">3-year revenue CAGR of -21.1%</cite>, indicating recent financial contraction.

confidence.notes: Strong financial transparency but limited outcome measurement.

alignment.explanation: The organization has a <cite id="7">verified zakat program</cite> and serves <cite id="17">underserved Muslim and local populations</cite> in high-urgency humanitarian areas.

credibility.explanation: IMAN is a highly credible institution with <cite id="12">100% independent board oversight</cite> and a <cite id="13">clear theory of change</cite>. However, it currently <cite id="16">meets 0 of 20 BBB Wise Giving Alliance standards</cite> due to a lack of formal review data.
credibility.improvement: To strengthen credibility, the organization should <cite id="16">complete the BBB Wise Giving Alliance accreditation process</cite> to verify its governance and effectiveness standards.

rich_narrative.headline: The Inner-City Muslim Action Network (IMAN) drives social justice and community health through holistic services for marginalized populations in Chicago and Atlanta.

ideal_donor_profile.best_for_summary: Best for donors who prioritize domestic social justice and holistic community health within an Islamic framework of service.
donor_motivations: Want to support 'Green ReEntry' for formerly incarcerated individuals
Value established institutions with a 25+ year track record
Prefer funding direct healthcare and housing services in US inner cities
giving_considerations: Program spending is lower than international relief benchmarks
Recent revenue trends show a significant downward trajectory
Focus is localized to specific urban centers (Chicago/Atlanta)
ideal_donor_profile.not_ideal_for: Donors seeking high-efficiency international relief or those who require rigorous RCT-level evidence of impact.

impact_evidence.evidence_grade_explanation: Grade C reflects a clear theory of change and direct service delivery, but a lack of verified outcome data or external evaluations.
impact_evidence.theory_of_change_summary: IMAN creates impact by providing integrated health, housing, and vocational training to stabilize returning citizens and marginalized residents.
impact_evidence.why_evidence_matters: Evidence ensures that transitional housing and health services are effectively reducing recidivism and improving community health outcomes.

long_term_outlook.room_for_funding_explanation: Despite recent revenue declines, the organization's large-scale health and housing infrastructure can absorb significant additional capital.

peer_comparison.differentiator: Distinguished by its <cite id="2">federally qualified health center status</cite> and domestic focus compared to international relief peers.

similar_organizations.differentiator: Similar focus on direct healthcare provision

strengths.detail: The organization demonstrates high fiscal discipline in its development efforts, <cite id="11">spending only $0.03 to raise every $1 in contributions</cite>.
IMAN maintains <cite id="8">9.9 months of working capital</cite>, providing significant stability to sustain operations during economic fluctuations.
The organization integrates <cite id="3">transitional housing, life skills, and construction training</cite> to provide a comprehensive support system for marginalized residents.

strengths_deep_dive: IMAN's strength lies in its long-term institutional stability and direct delivery model. Since its <cite id="1">founding in 1997</cite>, it has built a deep infrastructure that includes <cite id="12">100% independent board members</cite> and a clear <cite id="13">documented theory of change</cite>. This institutional maturity is reflected in its ability to generate <cite id="6">$2,979,023 in program service revenue</cite>, indicating that its services, such as the health center, have reached a level of operational integration that provides sustainable income beyond traditional donations.
rich_narrative.summary: The Inner-City Muslim Action Network (IMAN) is a community-driven organization <cite id="1">founded in 1997</cite> that operates at the intersection of health, housing, and social justice. Based in Chicago and Atlanta, IMAN provides a holistic model of service delivery, including a <cite id="2">federally qualified health center</cite> and specialized programs for <cite id="3">returning citizens through its Green ReEntry initiative</cite>. The organization reported <cite id="4">total revenue of $15,923,414</cite> in its most recent fiscal year, with a diversified funding base that includes <cite id="5">$12,509,163 in contributions</cite> and nearly <cite id="6">$3 million in program service revenue</cite>. IMAN is recognized for its <cite id="7">zakat-eligible programs</cite>, which support the poor, the needy, and those in the path of God (fisabilillah) through direct humanitarian services. While the organization maintains <cite id="8">9.9 months of working capital</cite>, its <cite id="9">program expense ratio of 65.9%</cite> is lower than the median for its peer group, suggesting opportunities for further operational scaling. Despite this, IMAN remains a cornerstone for marginalized populations, leveraging <cite id="10">29 years of experience</cite> to address systemic poverty and health disparities.
